column4: I am running ubuntu 8.10 and cannot ping any local FQDN, I can ping any machine and I get back my IP and the FQDN in the ping output
I cannot ping my FQDN it times out.  any clues?
do you have other network connection problems, or just with icmp?
just ping I haven't tested anything else

a couple of possibilities: 1) the machines are configured to ignore pings, and drop them silently, leaving you with a timeout (not very likely) 2) you have a bad routing table (view it with "/sbin/route -n"), and you need to set a route to the network that you wish to reach.
I can ping the machine just not the FQDN
so it's not routing issues right?
in that case, it's probably a dns issue
any idea how one might fix it?
if by "ping the machine", you mean "ping the ip address, instead of the name".
yes, you can contact the guy who administers your local dns :-)
an easy way to tell: try "dig <hostname>", and see what comes back.
install "dnsutils" if you don't have dig.
pinging the ip and hostname work, just not the fqdn..
then what does dig say about the fqdn?
where do you want me to paste the result?
whichever pastebin you like, but i need to be gone in about three minutes, so you'll need to ask someone else to take a look :-)
oh ok thanks for the help
